name: Terminating fixed point
intro: As can be seen from the previous chapter, every combinator has at least one fixed point.
However, it's not guaranteed to reach the normal form.
But in some cases it does, i.e. an equation of form f x = x
has a specific solution x for a given f.
Typically such solution requires additional arguments for verification.

content.title: Easy ones first
descr: Find x such that B x a b = x a b.
Since B requires 3 arguments to resolve into something else,
you'll need to provide two extra variables on the left, and, subsequently, on the right.
This logic applies to the following tasks as well.

content.title: Kestrel's favourite
descr: Find x such that K x = x. It might be hiding among the above quests.
The theorem about the properties of every fixed point of K is one of the exercises
Unfortunately, the margins of this interpreter are too narrow to verify proofs...

content.title: Use the force, Luke
descr: Remember, T a b = b a. Find x such that T x = x.
You might have to resort to an actual fixed point calculation from the last chapter.

content.title: Cardinal
content.hint: Can't make different variables indistinguishable? Discard them!

content.title: Iota
descr: Given ι = z → x S K, find x such that ι x = x.
As of this writing, I have no idea how to solve it, aside from adding more variables
and cycling through x=K, x=S, x=Kx<sub>0</sub>, x=Sx<sub>1</sub>y<sub>1</sub>,
repeating the process for new unknowns if necessary.
I happen to know the solutoin by chance though.
cases: iot=z->zSK; iot x a b c d e f
x a b c d e f
